raw_text:
Disappointed Scott in solid start
 
 Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit.
 
 The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equalled the Spanish record.
 
 Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64secs but ran 0.04secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final. "I should have done better than that," he said. "I felt I could have won it. I got a poor start - but I still felt I should have ran faster." Vivancos slashed his personal best to equal the Spanish record with a time of 7.60secs while Kronberg and Dorival clocked 7.62secs and 7.63secs respectively.

He was slightly behind Felipe Vivancos, who set a new Spanish record with a time of 7.60 seconds, followed by Robert Kronberg and Dudley Dorival in 7.62 and 7.63 seconds respectively.

Vivancos slashed his personal best to equal the Spanish record with a time of 7.60secs while Kronberg and Dorival clocked 7.62secs and 7.63secs respectively.
smollm:1.7b:
Scott was disappointed in his performance at the European Indoor Championships, but he did not rule out challenging for a medal next week. He finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Madrid meet, which is below the Spanish record. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos and he equalled the Spanish record.
Scott's first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final was also disappointing, but he did not feel he should have done better than that. He got a poor start in his heat, but he still felt he could have won it if he had run faster. Scott's personal best time of 7.64secs is slower than the Spanish record, but he still feels he should have been able to beat it.
Scott's performance at the IAAF Indoor Championships was disappointing, but he did not rule out challenging for a medal next week. He finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Madrid meet and was second in his heat at the IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let me tackle this query step by step. The user has provided a text and wants it summarized into one concise paragraph. I need to make sure I capture the key points without any extra information.

First, I'll read through the original text carefully. It starts with Scott's disappointment in his first start but then clarifies that he had a good debut on the international circuit. He was expected to compete at the European Indoor Championships next week. 

I notice several details: Allan Scott finished fourth in 60m hurdles in Madrid, didn't rule out future medals. Other competitors include Robert Kronberg from Sweden and Dudley Dorival from Haiti, who set a personal best equaling the Spanish record.

The user emphasized Scott's disappointment in his final race but also highlighted his potential for success next week. He noted that he felt confident but had a slight setback with a 0.04-second slower finish. He acknowledged others' performances and mentioned Vivancos breaking the record.

I need to condense this into a single summary, keeping all these points relevant without getting bogged down by specifics. I'll focus on his confidence, his debut strength, next tournament expectation, and his personal feedback from the final race.
</think>

Allan Scott is confident of winning medals at the European Indoor Championships after a strong first start on the international circuit. He finished fourth in the 60m hurdles in Madrid but expressed disappointment due to a slight setback finishing 0.04 seconds slower than expected, though he felt a path forward for next week's event. Other competitors included Robert Kronberg from Sweden and Dudley Dorival from Haiti, who set a personal best equaling the Spanish record of 7.60 seconds.

Although disappointed with his performance, he was determined to challenge for a medal next weekend. During this time, Scott had been training intensely and is currently focused on improving his technique and strength to perform even better at the upcoming European Indoor Championships in Birmingham, England.
